lines.text: Love transcends death. The people we love touch our lives, even after they're gone.
Good morning, Miss Parker. Broots.
Sydney.
You're looking... refreshed.
New underpants will do that to you.
[Miss Parker and Broots look at each other silently]
Sydney, you made a funny.
Stole it, I'm afraid. Last night, I went on a date.
You had a date!

[to Broots]
That's when two people actually meet instead of typing to each other on a computer keyboard.
[to Sydney]
So, if it was a date, how can you be sure that those are *your* underpants?
I found something bizarre.
What, like hair on your head?
No, that would be fantasy. This is real.
Maybe I should send you to every Y.M.C.A. in the country first. Or lock you in the Bates Motel with Sydney and Broots.
This is about that strip search in Las Vegas, isn't it?
Karma. Ain't it a bitch?
Why did you save my life?
Because I still remember the little girl who gave me my first kiss.
[to Broots' daughter Debbie]
no running, no playing, no feet on the furniture, and no noise, which includes crying and whining. Be invisible and we'll get along just fine.
How do you think he will hold up?
Before or after he wets his pants?
Have you ever gone to church?
With all I've seen and done, a church is the last place I should be.
Or the first.
When in doubt, lie.
I, uh, know it's none of my business, Syd, but sometimes Memory Lane can be a dead-end street.

We both know that this notion of human equality perpetuates mediocrity. But we're not mediocre, are we, Miss Parker? We're independent - and independence - that's a privilege of the strong. Tell me, Miss Parker, how strong are you?
Since when do you hate to fly?
I don't hate to fly. I hate to barf.
Trust can kill you or set you free.
What do you want?
Isn't it obvious? I want everything.
I want to know who I am. And I'd rather die trying to find out than live not knowing.
Actually Ms. Parker, I don't think we're in Kansas any more.
Are you telling me you've never been to a strip club before? You know, strange men cramming sweaty wads of cash into strange women's panties?
I think I would remember THAT.
Topless?
What? You've never been in a strip joint before? Naked women swinging around metal poles, strange men cramming sweaty wads of money into strange women's panties?
I would remember something like that...
You know the rumor that JFK was kept alive as a vegetable somewhere? Buzzie claims it was right here in SL-18.
Yeah, next to the alien corpses Nixon showed Jackie Gleason.
That was here too?

[after asking the foreman about the sulfuric chloride]
One more question.
Shoot.
Valentine's Day. Specifically cupid.
Yeah.
A corpulent infant, who happens to be an archer, goes around shooting arrows into people and suddenly they're in love?
That's about it.
And to show that they love, people buy each other chocolate and other sweets? Do they want to be fat, like the infant?
You mean a shrink, don't you? Thanks Syd, but I'll leave the mental masturbation to someone else.
Jarod, if you ever wanta get together, pick each other's brains, little one-on-one...
Careful Claire, don't cross a line you can't come back from.

[Referring to her nicotine patch]
The only way this thing is gonna help me is if I roll it and smoke it.
The Centre wants him alive.
Preferably.
a tiny little door marked 'exit.'
Well maybe it's time to run for it.
So full of anger!
That's my religion.
God forgives. I don't.
Here you go. Breakfast.
That isn't wheat grass and tomato juice.
Jarod, why don't you tell the group what brought you here?
A large cop with bad breath.
You believe someone stole your mother's body?
Except for this Scotch-induced earthquake rattling between my ears, I'm not sure exactly what to believe anymore.
Let's face it, Sydney. Catherine Parker's body being gone fits in with all the other bizarre happenings around here. The reappearance of Edna Raines, who, after 30 years, everyone thought was dead...
And now who really is dead, thanks to the Bald Butcher she called hubby.
I never thought I'd hear you say 'murder is business as usual,' Syd.
Trust your inner sense, Miss Parker. I do.
How come you know so much about Greek lore?
I did a lot of frat boys in college.
Make up your mind, Sydney. Be a scientist or a mommy. You can't be both.
44 a.m., waking her up]
What?
Oh, I intentially wake you in your deepest sleep phase and all I get is a lifeless 'what'?
You up for a dogfight?
Me? I was born for this moment.
You can only be a jinx if you believe in luck.
[Sydney is on the phone with Jarod and Broots is trying to trace the call]
Keep talking. We've almost got him.
[Jarod flips a switch on a box near his phone, causing a high-pitched sound to terminate any sort of trace to his phone]
Tell Broots I discovered RadioShack.
Get back to me, Sydney. I'm running late.
For what?
Justice.
So, you're a doctor *and* a lawyer?
And I'm working on Indian chief.
Actually, I offer a very valuable service. You'd be surprised how many cab drivers won't pick up a man in a dress.
Really? Why?
The truth is, I'd like to offer my services as your personal chauffeur.
No kidding! That's great! Now, you're sure you have a driver's license?
Don't worry, boss. You're in good hands. And I promise to be the perfect lady.
Hey, baby!
Up yours, pal!

[to Miss Parker]
Is today your birthday? How old are you?
[Miss Parker glares at him]
Young, I'm sure.

[groans and bends over in pain]
Oh, no.
Your ulcer? And no medication.
Ladies and gentlemen. The fabulous Sherlock Holmes.

[laughing]
Here I am, trying to comfort you.

[looking hurt]
As if anything you could ever do would give me comfort?

[quickly sobers]
It did once.
You can't save them all, Jarod. You may be a Pretender, but you're human.

[referring to the champagne Miss Parker is drinking]
That isn't good for your ulcer.
Neither are you.
You make the rules.
That's just the way I like it.
Bernice and I went to this amusing little place, The Chocolat.
[Broots and Miss Parker burst out laughing]
You, uh, you, you, you went to a comedy club.
New experiences keep my psychiatric skills finely tuned.
Not to mention that slam-bang wit.
Exactly! How many psychiatrists does it take to change one lightbulb?
Call the hotel and book us some rooms for this shindig.
[puts unlit cigarette in mouth]
Oh, Jarod already did.
[Miss Parker lights cigarette]
They're, uh, non-smoking rooms.

[takes drag and smiles]
Perfect.
[exhales smoke]

[to Jarod, after he meets her face-to-face]
You've got quite a set, showing up here.

[about Angelo]
Cousin It woke up and remembered he was Liberace.

[about borrowing Angelo from Mr Raines]
Uncle Fester will never know his Lurch is missing.

[to Broots]
You look like you need to change your pamper.
Sydney, step back. I wouldn't want you to get brain matter all over your new suit.
So, how long have you been a lawyer?
About... seven minutes.
I decide who lives or dies.

[to Jarod after he is injured and they are surrounded]
Go! Find our parents!
[gives Jarod their father's medal]
Don't tell them what I became.

[as he is dying in Jarod's arms]
I'm sorry, Jarod.
For what?
For everything.
[Kyle's hand slips out of Jarod's and he dies]

[about Kyle whose heart was transplanted into a young boy after his death]
Good for you, little brother. Good for you.

[after Kyle saves him]
They said you were dead.
Not hardly, big brother.
Don't worry, sheriff. I'm no hero.
Ive been angry for so long, so filled with rage and revenge, Ive forgotten what it was like to care about someone.
[upon seeing Lyle after Kyle has beaten him for kidnapping Jarod]
Kyle, what happened to him?
He tripped and hit his head.

[as he rescues Kyle who is still unaware that they are brothers]
I'm Jarod.
Raines said Jarod was dead.
Not hardly.

You shouldn't underestimate Jarod. And you should never underestimate me. And the next time that you send me into a building that is gonna explode, it had better blow, because if it doesn't it's gonna be your gray matter they will be mopping up with a toothbrush.
Miss Parker!
[hugs Miss Parker]
Do you want me to hurt you?
